input_question: What are the main detectors proposed for the Electron-Ion Collider (EIC)? What are the optical processes involved in Cherenkov detectors? How is AI being utilized for imaging Cherenkov detectors at EIC?
output_claims: ["Main detectors proposed for the Electron-Ion Collider (EIC)", "Optical processes involved in Cherenkov detectors", "Utilization of AI for imaging Cherenkov detectors at EIC"]
output_complete_response: All detector designs proposed for EIC have a dual radiator ring-imaging Cherenkov detector (dRICH) in the hadron direction, detection of internally reflected Cherenkov light (DIRC) in the barrel, and a modular-aerogel RICH (mRICH) in the electron direction. Cherenkov detectors involve optical processes with many photons that need to be tracked through complex surfaces, making these detectors relatively slow to simulate. AI is being utilized for optimizing the design of Cherenkov detectors and for reducing the computing budget necessary to explore a large number of design points.,
output_individual_response: ["dual radiator ring-imaging Cherenkov detector (dRICH), detection of internally reflected Cherenkov light (DIRC), and a modular-aerogel RICH (mRICH)", "Optical processes with many photons that need to be tracked through complex surfaces", "AI is being utilized for optimizing the design of Cherenkov detectors and for reducing the computing budget necessary to explore a large number of design points"]

input_question: What are the three criteria for constructing the novel SIDIS observable, q∗? What is the expected detector resolution for q∗ versus ⃗PhT?
output_claims: ["Three criteria for constructing the novel SIDIS observable, q∗", "Expected detector resolution for q∗ versus ⃗PhT"]
output_complete_response: The three criteria for constructing the novel SIDIS observable, q∗, are (i) it is purely defined in terms of lab-frame angles and the beam energies; (ii) at small values q∗≪Q, the differential cross section d σ/dq∗, including spin correlations, still satisfies a rigorous factorization theorem in terms of the standard TMD PDFs and FFs; (iii) it does not dilute the statistical power of the available event sample. The expected detector resolution for q∗ versus ⃗PhT is shown in Fig. 2, where q∗ improves over the resolution of PhT/z by an order of magnitude across the strongly confined TMD region q∗, PhT/z<∼2 GeV.
output_individual_response: ["(i) it is purely defined in terms of lab-frame angles and the beam energies; (ii) at small values q∗≪Q, the differential cross section d σ/dq∗, including spin correlations, still satisfies a rigorous factorization theorem in terms of the standard TMD PDFs and FFs; (iii) it does not dilute the statistical power of the available event sample", "q∗ improves over the resolution of PhT/z by an order of magnitude across the strongly confined TMD region q∗, PhT/z<∼2 GeV"]

input_question: What is the significance of the observable q∗ in the context of TMD physics? What is the construction of q∗ based on? What is the expected improvement in resolution of q∗ compared to PhT/z?
output_claims: ["Significance of the observable q∗ in TMD physics", "Construction of q∗", "Expected improvement in resolution of q∗ compared to PhT/z"]
output_complete_response: The observable q∗ is significant in TMD physics as it is designed to be maximally resilient against resolution effects while delivering the same sensitivity to TMD dynamics as ⃗PhT. The construction of q∗ is purely defined in terms of lab-frame angles and the beam energies. It is based on the high-precision reconstruction of polar angles and azimuthal angles in the EIC lab frame. The expected improvement in resolution of q∗ compared to PhT/z is an order of magnitude across the strongly confined TMD region q∗, PhT/z<∼2 GeV.
output_individual_response: ["q∗ is designed to be maximally resilient against resolution effects", "q∗ is purely defined in terms of lab-frame angles and the beam energies", "An order of magnitude improvement across the strongly confined TMD region q∗, PhT/z<∼2 GeV"]

input_question: What is the energy dependence of the total cross section for real Compton scattering at Q2=0? What is the energy dependence of the total cross section for very high Q2?
output_claims: ["Energy dependence of the total cross section for real Compton scattering at Q2=0", "Energy dependence of the total cross section for very high Q2"]
output_complete_response: The total cross section for real Compton scattering at Q2=0 is dominated by soft-pomeron exchange with an additional contribution from reggeon exchange at lower energies. The cross sections rise with energy as W^2ǫ1 at Q2=0 and change to W^2ǫ0 for very high Q2. Here, ǫ1≈0.09 and ǫ0≈0.30 are the intercept parameters of the soft and hard pomerons, respectively.,
output_individual_response: ["Rise with energy as W^2ǫ1 at Q2=0", "Change to W^2ǫ0 for very high Q2"]

input_question: What is the method used to extract the diﬀractive longitudinal structure function?
output_claims: ["method used to extract the diﬀractive longitudinal structure function"]
output_complete_response: The extraction of the diﬀractive longitudinal structure function FD(3) L is performed using the same method as in the H1 analysis [22]. This method was adapted from the measurements of the inclusive longitudinal structure function FL, see [52–54]. The reduced cross section is a linear function of YL, see Eq. (8). The structure function FD(3) L can thus be found by performing a linear ﬁt, and extracting the slope of σD(3) red as a function of YL.,
output_individual_response: ["linear fit method"]
